page.title: 11LANDSC. BUILD. CHELWOOD G.
page.content: The underlying geology is beds of Ash- down sand, of cretaceous age, very inconstant in character, with sub- ordinate seams of clay and silt and capped by a thin but widespread pebble bed. Erosion of these beds has pro- duced the stream vallyes which charac- terize the area. The mediaeval pale of the Royal hunting forest remains while cultivation has resulted in some rough grazing and fruit farming. There are three significant mansions: Birch Grove House, Wych Cross Place and Chelwood Vachery. The oldest building is Legges and Sedges Farm and there are two public houses and one hotel.
